title: Why are the Minnesota Twins always mediocre?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)


The Minnesota Twins have been a pretty mediocre team the past few years, only making the postseason twice in the past five years. The Twins always seem to have a decent team each year but as fans know, they struggle to get over the hump and compete with the top teams in the league.


Code
teamstats25 <- read_csv("mlbteam25.csv")

twins25 <- teamstats25 |> 
  filter(Tm == "Minnesota Twins")

mets25 <- teamstats25 |>
  filter(Tm == "New York Mets")

dodgers25 <- teamstats25 |>
  filter(Tm == "Los Angeles Dodgers")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=teamstats25, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=twins25, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="blue") +
  geom_point(data=mets25, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="orange") +
  geom_point(data=dodgers25, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="lightblue") +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=twins25, 
    aes(x=W, y=ERA, label=Tm)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=mets25, 
    aes(x=W, y=ERA, label=Tm)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=dodgers25, 
    aes(x=W, y=ERA, label=Tm)
     ) +
  labs(
    x="Wins", 
    y="Earned Run Average", 
    title="The Twins are keeping up with the rest of the league in pitching this season", 
    subtitle="Through the first few weeks of the season the twins have been kepping a sub-four ERA", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Walter Brandt"
    ) +
   theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The Twins are keeping up with the top teams in terms of earned run average. But where they are not keeping up is wins in 2025. If the Twins pitching staff can keep a sub three earned run average you can expect them to move up in terms of wins throughout the 2025 season.


Code
pitching24 <- read_csv("teamstats24.csv")

twins24 <- pitching24 |> 
  filter(Tm == "Minnesota Twins")

mets24 <- pitching24 |>
  filter(Tm == "New York Mets")

dodgers24 <- pitching24 |>
  filter(Tm == "Los Angeles Dodgers")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=pitching24, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=twins24, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="blue") +
  geom_point(data=mets24, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="orange") +
  geom_point(data=dodgers24, aes(x=W, y=ERA), color="lightblue") +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=twins24, 
    aes(x=W, y=ERA, label=Tm)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=mets24, 
    aes(x=W, y=ERA, label=Tm)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=dodgers24, 
    aes(x=W, y=ERA, label=Tm)
     ) +
  labs(
    x="Wins", 
    y="Earned Run Average", 
    title="Minnesota's average pitching", 
    subtitle="The Twins land somewhere in the middle of the pack when looking ar ERA and wins", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Walter Brandt"
    ) +
   theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Looking at the Twins pitching in 2024, they have a sub five earned run average, which puts them in the bottom half of the league in terms of earned runs. It’s pretty obvious that this level of pitching does not result in a team that can go deep into the playoffs. Or even make the playoffs at all.

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=fielding24, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=mnfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="blue") +
  geom_bar(data=cwsfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="black") +
  geom_bar(data=ladfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="lightblue") +
  geom_bar(data=detfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="navy") +

  geom_bar(data=clefielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#E50022") +
  geom_bar(data=kcfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#BD9B60") +
  geom_bar(data=balfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#DF4601") +
  geom_bar(data=nyyfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#0C2340") +
  geom_bar(data=nymfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#FF5910") +
  geom_bar(data=milfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#FFC52F") +
  geom_bar(data=phifielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#E81828") +
  geom_bar(data=atlfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#CE1141") +
  geom_bar(data=atlfielding, aes(x=reorder(Tm, Rtot), weight=Rtot), fill="#2F241D") +
  
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Fielding Runs Above Average", 
    title="The Twins are terrible at fielding", 
    subtitle="Minnesota ranks in the bottom three of all MLB teams in Rtot", 
    caption="Source: Baeball Reference | By Walter Brandt"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Where else do the Twins struggle? Looking at a stat called Rtot, which basically means how good they are at stopping the ball on defense. The Twins were quite abysmal in this category in 2024 being third to last only to the Marlins and White Sox, who barely combined for 100 wins total last year.


Code

twinsbatting25 |>

At this point, Twins fans expect Byron Buxton to never finish an entire season due to him getting injured seemingly every year since he put on a Twins jersey. But what happens when he is in the lineup? As we can see, Byron Buxton leads the Twins in hits(tied with Ty France) and is also second in runs batted in. If he can just stay healthy Buxton will be a crucial assest to the Minnesota Twins. His batting and fielding ability is that of an elite player when he is healthy.
All in all, the Minnesota Twins are decent and not much more than that. This is due to subpar fielding, mediocre pitching and injuries. The Twins could be shaping up to have a great 2025, as they been heating up the past few weeks after a slow start to the season. If the Twins can maintain a sub-three earned run average, keep Buxton healthy and get better at fielding they should make a postseason apperance in 2025.

title: Looking back at the Chicago Bears disappointing 2024 season
text:
The Chicago Bears went into the 2024 season with high hopes after drafting Caleb Williams with the first overall pick in last year’s draft. Fans would be let down after the Bears went on to go 5-12, finishing in last place in the NFC North. It is not all doom and gloom for Chicago, they did bad enough to get yet another top ten draft pick in this year’s draft.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)
offstats <- read_csv("nfl24.csv")

bears <- offstats |>
  filter(
    Team == "Chicago Bears"
  ) 
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=offstats, aes(x=reorder(Team, PF), weight=PF), fill="lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=bears, aes(x=reorder(Team, PF), weight=PF), fill="orange") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Points For", 
    title="Chicago's offensive struggles", 
    subtitle="The Bears are at the bottom of the barrel for NFL offense", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Walter Brandt"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )  









There was a lot of hype going into the 2024 season with what analysts said was one of the best wide receiver cores in the league with DJ Moore, Rome Odunze and Keenan Allen who the Bears traded for from the Chargers in the offseason. Although there were some flashes of promise last season, it is clear that the Bears struggled heavily with their rookie quarterback and abysmal offensive line. The Bears finished amongst the worst teams in the NFL this year in terms of points for.
It’s tough to win when you can’t score. But why can’t the Bears seem to put points on the board?


Code
rushing24 <- read.csv("rushing.csv")

bearsrushing <- rushing24 |> 
  filter(Team == "Chicago Bears") 

eaglesrush <- rushing24 |> 
  filter(Team == "Philadelphia Eagles")

vikesrush <- rushing24 |> 
  filter(Team == "Minnesota Vikings")

lionsrush <- rushing24 |> 
  filter(Team == "Detroit Lions")

packrush <- rushing24 |> 
  filter(Team == "Green Bay Packers")



ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data=rushing24, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, size=Yds), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_point(
    data=bearsrushing, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, size=Yds), color="orange") +
  geom_point(
    data=vikesrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, size=Yds), color="purple") +
  geom_point(
    data=lionsrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, size=Yds), color="blue") +
  geom_point(
    data=packrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, size=Yds), color="yellow") + geom_point(
    data=eaglesrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, size=Yds), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 28.4375) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 1.95) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=vikesrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, label=Team)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=bearsrushing, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, label=Team)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=packrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, label=Team)
     ) +
  geom_text_repel(
     data=lionsrush, 
    aes(x=BrkTkl, y=YAC.Att, label=Team)
     ) +
 labs(
    x="Broken Tackles", 
    y="Yards after contact per attempt", 
    title="The Bears frail run game", 
    subtitle="Chicago Ranks second to last in broken tackles, second to last in yards after contact", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Walter Brandt"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The Bears claimed De’andre Swift in free agency which had players and fans alike excited about a dual threat offense but there was not much of a threat, especially in the run game. The Bears were second to last in broken tackles with only 12. Chicago was also second to last place in yards after contact per attempt. It doesn’t take a football guru to know that you need a good run game to open up the pass game. Not being able to break tackles and not running for many yards gives way for longer second downs, making it much harder for an offense to have prolonged drives, wearing out the opposing defense and giving your defense a breather.
As everyone knows Caleb Williams was hit a lot in his rookie season. But let’s look at him compared to his peers.

passing24 |>

It’s expected for a rookie quarterback to struggle in their first season. However Caleb Williams took a beating his first year, leading the league in sacks. Although he led the league by a decent margin other quarterbacks got sacked a lot as well. However, what is different for Williams is the amount of yards he lost by getting sacked.
Sure, Chicago’s offense isn’t all there. But they have a great defense, right?


Code
advdef <- read_csv("defadv.csv")

HurryPCT <- advdef |>
  mutate(HrryPCT=gsub("%","",HrryPCT)) |>
  mutate(HrryPCT=as.numeric(HrryPCT))


bearsadvdef <- HurryPCT|>
  filter(Team == "Chicago Bears")



ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=HurryPCT, aes(x=HrryPCT, y=Hrry), color="lightgrey") +
   geom_point(
    data=bearsadvdef, 
    aes(x=HrryPCT, y=Hrry), color="black") +
  labs(
    x="Hurry Percent", 
    y="Hurrys", 
    title="The Bears defense gives QBs too much time", 
    subtitle="Chicago is in the bottom of the middle in hurrying the opposing QB", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Walter Brandt"
    ) + 
  geom_text_repel(
     data=bearsadvdef, 
    aes(x=HrryPCT, y=Hrry, label=Team)
     ) +
  theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









When most people think about the Bears they think of the Monsters of the Midway and hard-nosed defense. However, in reality the Bears were really not that great on defense either. One thing to look at is their quarterback hurries and hurry percent. They rank somewhere in the bottom middle meaning that they give opposing quarterbacks too much time to make a decision leading to big plays.
A bad offense and a promising, yet less than proficient defense definitely did not do Chicago any favors last year. When you can’t score it makes it hard to win. It also makes it hard to win when running backs can’t break tackles and an offensive line allows their rookie quarterback to get sacked 68 times. Add all of that on top of a mediocre defense and that is a recipe for an awful season.
